articles.headline: Jordanian Pilot’s Death, Shown in ISIS Video, Spurs Jordan to Execute Prisoners
articles.snippet: After a video appeared to show the burning of First Lt. Moaz al-Kasasbeh, Jordan executed Sajida al-Rishawi — who was convicted in a suicide bombing plot — and a top lieutenant of Al Qaeda in Iraq.
articles.abstract: After a video appeared to show the burning of First Lt. Moaz al-Kasasbeh, Jordan executed Sajida al-Rishawi — who was convicted in a suicide bombing plot — and a top lieutenant of Al Qaeda in Iraq.
articles.lead_paragraph: AMMAN, Jordan — When relatives learned Tuesday night that the Islamic State had released a video showing the death of a Jordanian fighter pilot, First Lt. Moaz al-Kasasbeh, they tried to keep it from his mother, Issaf, and his wife, Anwar. They switched off the television and tried to wrest a smartphone out of his wife’s hand, but she had already seen a mobile news bulletin.
articles.byline: By Rod Nordland and Ranya Kadri

articles.headline: Proposal for a Theme Park Draws From Crimea’s Distant Past
articles.snippet: As the French operators of a popular historical theme park look to expand into Crimea, one question is, whose version of history will the park depict?
articles.abstract: As the French operators of a popular historical theme park look to expand into Crimea, one question is, whose version of history will the park depict?
articles.lead_paragraph: LES EPESSES, France — Philippe and Nicolas de Villiers, father and son, run one of France’s most popular theme parks, a grand and gaudy take on the country’s past. So naturally, they are planning to expand. To Crimea.

articles.headline: Local Politics Are Fracturing European Unity
articles.snippet: Advocates of the eurozone have failed to grasp the crucial obstacle to their economic plan: Politics are still local.
articles.abstract: Advocates of the eurozone have failed to grasp the crucial obstacle to their economic plan: Politics are still local.
articles.lead_paragraph: The euro had been enshrined in a treaty but not yet come to life in the autumn of 1997, when Martin Feldstein, the influential president of the National Bureau of Economic Research, published an essay arguing that European leaders’ hopes that a monetary union would foster greater harmony and peace in a Continent repeatedly ravaged by wars were misplaced.

articles.headline: Coming to Mourn Tahrir Square’s Dead, and Joining Them Instead
articles.snippet: Shaimaa el-Sabbagh, a 31-year-old woman killed at a memorial in Cairo, has become a symbol of the Egyptian authorities’ intolerance of protest.
articles.abstract: Shaimaa el-Sabbagh, a 31-year-old woman killed at a memorial in Cairo, has become a symbol of the Egyptian authorities’ intolerance of protest.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Her friends wanted to lay a wreath in Tahrir Square as a memorial, but Shaimaa el-Sabbagh urged them to reconsider. She feared that the police might attack, mistaking them for supporters of the outlawed Muslim Brotherhood, said a cousin, Sami Mohamed Ibrahim.

articles.headline: When Company Is Fined, Taxpayers Often Share Bill
articles.snippet: Companies can often reduce punitive damages through a tax loophole that permits them to deduct such payments as an ordinary business expense.
articles.abstract: Companies can often reduce punitive damages through a tax loophole that permits them to deduct such payments as an ordinary business expense.
articles.lead_paragraph: When a Montana judge ordered Hyundai to pay $73 million in punitive damages last year to the families of two teenagers killed in a car crash, she found that the South Korean automaker had “recklessly” ignored scores of warnings over more than a decade about the steering defect blamed for the accident.

articles.headline: Low Energy Prices Offer Opening for Subsidy Cuts
articles.snippet: Middle Eastern and developing countries have long kept oil cheap for political reasons, but a new global energy picture presents an opportunity to stop.
articles.abstract: Middle Eastern and developing countries have long kept oil cheap for political reasons, but a new global energy picture presents an opportunity to stop.
articles.lead_paragraph: In Saudi Arabia, drivers pay roughly 45 cents a gallon to fill up their cars, and in Venezuela even less. Energy is so inexpensive in Kuwait and Qatar that residents chill their enormous swimming pools in the summer and typically leave their air-conditioners on at full blast while they are away on vacation.

articles.headline: S.&P. Settlement Leaves Future Unclear for Ratings
articles.snippet: In the wake of the financial crisis, when rating agencies were blamed for feeding a subprime mortgage frenzy, Congress used the Dodd-Frank Act to adopt a battery of changes for the rating industry.
articles.abstract: In the wake of the financial crisis, when rating agencies were blamed for feeding a subprime mortgage frenzy, Congress used the Dodd-Frank Act to adopt a battery of changes for the rating industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: It cost $1.37 billion, but Standard & Poor’s has finally appeared to close the darkest chapter in its 150-year history as a rating agency.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Nathaniel Popper

articles.headline: Moussaoui Calls Saudi Princes Patrons of Al Qaeda
articles.snippet: Zacarias Moussaoui, a former Qaeda operative, said that members of the royal family were donors in the 1990s, and that he discussed plans to shoot down Air Force One with a staff member at the Saudi Embassy.
articles.abstract: Zacarias Moussaoui, a former Qaeda operative, said that members of the royal family were donors in the 1990s, and that he discussed plans to shoot down Air Force One with a staff member at the Saudi Embassy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In highly unusual testimony inside the federal supermax prison, a former operative for Al Qaeda has described prominent members of Saudi Arabia’s royal family as major donors to the terrorist network in the late 1990s and claimed that he discussed a plan to shoot down Air Force One with a Stinger missile with a staff member at the Saudi Embassy in Washington.

articles.headline: China Moves to Free Up Money in Its Economy
articles.snippet: A half-percentage-point cut in the reserve requirement for banks has the country’s central bank joining those taking measures to support growth.
articles.abstract: A half-percentage-point cut in the reserve requirement for banks has the country’s central bank joining those taking measures to support growth.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — China signaled fresh concerns about its slowing economy as the country’s central bank moved on Wednesday to stimulate growth by freeing up more money for banks to lend.

articles.headline: Despite Recalls, G.M. Pays Workers a Big Bonus
articles.snippet: The automaker’s workers will receive profit-sharing payouts of up to $9,000 each, after the company opted not to factor in recall costs.
articles.abstract: The automaker’s workers will receive profit-sharing payouts of up to $9,000 each, after the company opted not to factor in recall costs.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — To cope with the gravest safety crisis in its history, General Motors has spent freely — almost $3 billion — to compensate accident victims and recall nearly 30 million vehicles.
